frameDefinitions: In this frame, a Booker brings about a situation where an Organization plans to provide Services to a Client at a particular Scheduled_time.
These are words relating to filling containers and covering areas with some thing, things or substance, the Theme.
An Agent performs a series of unspecified tasks to plan for an Event to take place at a Scheduled_time and Place.
An Agent schedules an Event to take place at a specified Scheduled_time and Place.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
Two (or more) people (the Interlocutors, also encodable as Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2) talk to one another.
frameExamples: We can <t>book</t> you a boatride on the Somme or a special tour of the Louvre .
Lionel Hutz <t>coated</t> the wall with paint.
I've <t>arranged</t> a breakfast meeting for you tomorrow morning with Mr. Huntsberger.
Gina <t>scheduled</t> a dentist appointment for Monday in Berkeley.
I would rather <t>discuss</t> politics with anyone but him.
listRoleDefinitions: The entity that is intended to receive the <fen>Services</fen> of the <fen>Organization</fen>.
The goods or labor that the <fen>Client</fen> requests the <fen>Organization</fen> preserve for future consumption or rendering.
The entity that enters into its records the request of the <fen>Client</fen> to retain <fen>Services</fen> in the future.
The future point in time when the <fen>Client</fen> arranges for the <fen>Organization</fen> to provide <fen>Services</fen>.
The entity that contacts the <fen>Organization</fen> directly.  In many if not most cases, a <fen>Booker</fen> is also a <fen>Client</fen>, but the roles may also be separated, e.g. a travel agent.
The time at which the reserving event takes place.
The location the <fen>Booker</fen> performs the action.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the actor who instigates the filling.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the physical object or substance which changes location.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the area or container being filled. Goal is generally the NP Object in this frame.
An event which brings about the filling of the <fen>Goal</fen>.
When the filling occurs.
Where the filling takes place.
The person who makes arrangements for the <fen>Event</fen> to take place at a <fen>Time</fen> and <fen>Place</fen>.
The incident for which the <fen>Agent</fen> has made arrangements.
The time for which the <fen>Agent</fen> has arranged the <fen>Event</fen>.
This role describes the time at which the arrangements are made.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> has made arrangements for the <fen>Event</fen> to take place.
The sentient being who schedules an <fen>Event</fen> to take place at a <fen>Time</fen> and <fen>Place</fen>.
The incident that the <fen>Agent</fen> has scheduled to take place at a <fen>Time</fen> and <fen>Place</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Event</fen> is scheduled to take place.
This role describes the time at which the scheduling occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> has scheduled the <fen>Event</fen> to take place.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen> is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>.  Thus a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that of <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Interlocutors</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by <ment>with</ment>).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Interlocutors</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Interlocutors</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.

<fen>Topic</fen> expresses the subject that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> are trying to come to some agreement about.  It may refer, for example, to an undesirable issue that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> want to have the proper response to, or it may refer more directly to an unresolved question.
The time at which the discussion takes place.
The location at which a discussion takes place.
listRoleExamples: Phil Collins booked his <fex>cockatoo</fex> into a $350-a-night pet hotel.
She reserved the room for the meeting <fex>for Tuesday</fex> .
The hotel reserved two rooms for me .
I booked the room for Monday <fex>only on Tuesday</fex> .
Rev. Lovejoy carefully brushed the rolls <fex>with butter</fex>.
<fex>Lucy</fex> organized a playdate for little Michael and Marcy.
I've already made <fex>vacation</fex> arrangements.
I've put together a luncheon <fex>for 12:30</fex>.
Lionel organized a meeting <fex>at the local pub</fex> to discuss the bleak future of our organization.
<fex>I</fex> set up a meeting with Carlos on Monday.
I'd like to set up <fex>a meeting with Mr. Hofmann</fex>.
Maria scheduled the appointment <fex>for Monday</fex>.
Gina scheduled a dentist appointment for Monday <fex>in Berkeley</fex>.
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
<fex>'I'd like an extension,'</fex> begged Pat.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.
I urged him to concede <fex>yesterday</fex>.
<fex>The President</fex> conferred with his top advisor.
The President debated <fex>with his top advisor</fex>.
(1) <fex>The President and his advisor</fex> discussed the Venezuelan situation briefly before the summit.
The President and his top advisors discussed <fex>the scandal</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> the participants discussed taking down the last trade barriers without consensus.
We just conferred for a couple of hours <fex>up in her room</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
